text:
“You’ve got rid of Marfa Petrovna, too?” Raskolnikov interrupted.

“Oh, you’ve heard that?” 

“I don’t know what to say,” the other replied. “My conscience is clear. The inquiry said apoplexy due to bathing after dinner. Nothing more.”

Raskolnikov laughed. “I wonder you trouble yourself about it!”

“Why laugh? I struck her twice with a switch. No marks, even. I know it was atrocious, but Marfa Petrovna likely enjoyed my ‘warmth.’ She had bored everyone with that letter.”

He paused, then continued, “Her first act was to order the carriage out.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the moral implications of his actions and the nature of human relationships, questioning whether he contributed to a calamity.
